awd_titl_txt: A Study of Stellar Pulsations in Eclipsing Binary Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
Among the ways by which astronomers measure fundamental properties of stars (such as mass, radius, temperature, and luminosity), two stand out: by using closely observing binary stars orbiting each other, and by studying oscillations in stars -- asteroseismology -- akin to how geologists study the Earth through seismology. This team at Villanova University seeks to bridge the two techniques by incorporating the physics of stellar pulsations into their eclipsing binary star computer code known as PHOEBE.  The project will provide the opportunity to better understand pulsating stars by studying their properties within eclipsing binary systems, and also the other way around, to learn how pulsations influence binarity.  The astronomy group at Villanova has a long tradition of involving undergraduates in their research programs. The project will involve two undergrads per year in this research.  Two community workshops will provide training in the use of PHOEBE for early career scientists, with special consideration given to geographic diversity, gender balance, and representation from traditionally underrepresented groups.  The research team will provide a PHOEBE interface to the virtual reality infrastructure CAVE (Cave Automatic Virtual Environment) at Villanova, and to off-the-shelf VR headsets. 

PHOEBE works on the premise that binary component surfaces can be approximated by a mesh of triangles where each triangle has an assigned set of local quantities (temperature, surface gravity, velocity, emergent intensity, etc). This mesh effectively describes physical circumstances across distorted surfaces and accounts for many effects we see manifested in binary star light curves: gravity brightening due to tidal interaction and rotation, surface brightness variation due to reflection, heating and limb darkening, prominences such as spots, and, through this project, stellar pulsations. Asteroseismologists are able to recover detailed information on stellar properties from the power spectra of the observed light curves, which are in turn used to deduce fundamental parameters of stars by way of the so-called scaling relations. Incorporating stellar pulsations into PHOEBE will provide fundamental stellar parameters of pulsating stars to 1% or better, thus validating asteroseismic scaling relations while providing asteroseismologists with accurate parameters for their models of stellar pulsation mechanisms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Universe is vast. If our Sun were the size of a basketball in Washington, D.C., then the nearest star, Proxima, would be a ping-pong ball in Hawai’i! Resolving a ping-pong ball in Hawai’i from the East coast of the United States is tricky to say the least. And that is just the nearest star; all other stars are farther than that. So measuring the fundamental properties of stars, such as their radius, is inherently difficult.

Unless, that is, if we are lucky. Imagine a system of two stars revolving around the mutual center of mass. Imagine further that, fortuitously, the orbital plane of the system is aligned with our line of sight. Then, as stars revolve, they will periodically eclipse one another, causing a periodic decrease in the light we gather here on Earth. These systems are called eclipsing binary stars. Of the 200 billion stars in our galaxy, there are around 1%, or 2 billion, eclipsing binary systems.

Going from measuring light to stellar properties is then a geometrical problem: eclipse durations tell us something about the radii, eclipse depths about surface brightnesses; eclipse separations tell us about orbital properties, and eclipse shapes inform us about other parameters such as temperatures, surface gravities, and abundances of heavy elements. Add the dynamical component and we can also infer stellar masses. The principal deliverable of this project is PHOEBE, a code that can do this for us: given observations, it can infer the fundamental properties of stars.

Pulsating stars are of special interest: their inner structure instabilities cause periodic oscillations that manifest themselves as light variations. Yet without knowing the fundamental properties of these pulsating stars, interpreting these light variations is again difficult. But if we found a pulsating star in an eclipsing binary system, then we can use the same principles described above to get fundamental parameters of the pulsating star. And that means a lot.

For one, measuring the mass and radius helps calibrate the so-called asteroseismic scaling relations: equations that connect oscillation properties to fundamental parameters. Sun-like stars exhibit oscillation patterns akin to sound produced by musical instruments; from the tone we can figure out what instrument produces the sound, and similarly from the oscillations we can figure out the properties of stars. A particular focus of this project was to introduce the models of stellar pulsations into PHOEBE so that both geometrical and pulsational physics can be accounted for simultaneously. This makes many an asteroseismologist happy as they can focus on their inner stellar structure models and instability studies knowing that they can trust the fundamental parameters of their stars.

PHOEBE is open source, free and released under the General Public License. This means that everyone is free to use it, redistribute it, and modify it to suit their own needs. It can be downloaded from the project homepage, http://phoebe-project.org, or from the github repository, https://github.com/phoebe-project. The NSF support has been paramount for the continued success of the PHOEBE project; thanks to the NSF support, PHOEBE continues to be developed. Every summer the team is hosting educational workshops targeted to junior research scientists, and the outcomes are already evident: PHOEBE is the most frequently used eclipsing binary modeling software today.
